section.title: PID Assignment Method Behavior
section.para: The behavior of the methods assignObjectPid(), assignVersionPid() and assignContentPid() depends currently on the infrastructure configuration. For objects and versions is the point of time - in relation to the public-status - when a PID has to be assigned independent configurable.

listitem.para: PID assignment methods add only the persistent identifier to the object and do not alter it otherwise. Especially version number or public-status leaved untouched.
Even if the assignment creates no new version the process creates a new event entry in the version history of the object.
Each object and each version of an object can only have one PID.

The point of time when a PID is to assign to an object or version could be configured via the escidoc-core.properties. If it is required that every released version of an Item has a PID so than is it configurable. See therefore the later description of the properties parameter.
In general is it possible to assign a PID for an object or version during the whole object lifetime, except the objects public-status is withdrawn.

section.title: Behavior Configuration
section.para: The behavior in which status of an Item or Container a PID could be assigned is currently configurable via escidoc-core[.custom].properties. (This is an interim solution an will probably be integrated in the upcoming Content Model.)
The properties influence the behavior globally, therefore is an object individual configuration currently not possible.
Three types of keys are defined in escidoc-core[.custom].properties to control PID assignments: setPidBeforeRelease, setPidAfterRelease and releaseWithoutPid.
These parameters are hierarchically grouped to address the corresponding object and the PID for a versionPid or object.

To define the behavior for the versions of Items is the full parameter name cmm.Item.versionPid.releaseWithoutPid to use. In comparing is the definition for the whole Item object to set via cmm.Item.objectPid.releaseWithoutPid.

section.title: Object PID
section.para: PID assigned to objects in public-status withdrawn is forbidden.

The behavior of the PID assignment is currently defined via the escidoc-core[.custom].properties. Depending on the configuration it is either possible to force that each release object/version is assigned with an objectPid. It is also possible to allow PID assignment after an object is set to status 'released'.

row.entry:
[true|false]
true Set true if Item or Container could set to public-status 'released' without persistent identifier for the object.
false Set false if each Item or Container must have an persistent identifier if it is set to 'released'.

[true|false]
true Set true if Item or Container could assigned with an persistent identifier before the object is set to public-status 'released'.
false Set false if it is not allowed to assign a persistent identifier to Item or Container if the public status is not 'released'.

[true|false]
true Set true if Item or Container could assigned with an persistent identifier after the object is set to public-status 'released'.
false Set false if it is not allowed to assign a persistent identifier to Item or Container if the public status is 'released'.

section.para: A right to assign a PID is currently bounded to the common rights of a granted role to alter an object in the corresponding version-status.
If, for example, only the depositor is allowed to change objects in status 'submitted' then is an PID assignment also only for user with at least depositor role possible.

section.title: Version PID
section.para: If the assignment of PID for certain object versions is possible depends on the public-status of the version and the configuration for the PID assignment behavior.

row.entry:
[true|false]
true Set true if the version of Item or Container could set to public-status 'released' without persistent identifier for the object.
false Set false if each version of Item or Container must have an persistent identifier if it is set to 'released'.

[true|false]
true Set true if a version of Item or Container could assigned with an persistent identifier before the object is set to public-status 'released'.
false Set false if it is not allowed to assign a persistent identifier to a version of Item or Container if the public status is not 'released'.

[true|false]
true Set true if the version of Item or Container could assigned with an persistent identifier after the object is set to public-status 'released'.
false Set false if it is not allowed to assign a persistent identifier to a version of Item or Container if the public status is 'released'.

section.para: If PID assignment is possible after a version has reached pubic-status released then could only user with the role of the System Administrator use assignVersionPid(). Because only the System Administrator has the right to alter versions in status released.

table.title: Required permissions depending on version-status for assignVersionPid()

section.title: Content PID
section.para: If the assignment of PID for certain Item content is possible depends on the public-status of the Item version and the configuration for the PID assignment behavior.

row.entry:
[true|false]
true Set true if the version of Item could set to public-status 'released' without persistent identifier for all Item contents.
false Set false if each version of Item must have an persistent identifier if it is set to 'released'.

[true|false]
true Set true if an Item content could be assigned with a persistent identifier before the Item is set to public-status 'released'.
false Set false if it is not allowed to assign a persistent identifier to an Item content if the public status is not 'released'.

[true|false]
true Set true if the Item content could be assigned with a persistent identifier after the Item is set to public-status 'released'.
false Set false if it is not allowed to assign a persistent identifier to an Item content if the public status is 'released'.

section.para: If PID assignment is possible after an Item version has reached pubic-status released then could only user with the role of the System Administrator use assignContentPid(). Because only the System Administrator has the right to alter versions in status released.
